radiographic_examinations.findings: Opacity, 3.8 by 2.3 cm, in the posterior segment of the right lower lobe of the lung that abutted the pleura, contained air bronchograms, and was suggestive of cancer.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: A CT scan obtained three years earlier had been normal. Follow-up CT scans showed the nodule decreased to 1.5 by 2.4 cm, then continued diminishing in size, and ultimately resolved. New nodules and thickening were noted three months later.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Nodule in the right lower lobe had decreased further in size and was almost linear in configuration, consistent with a resolving inflammatory process.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: The prior nodule decreased in size, showing improvement.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Two new nodules, each 7 mm in diameter, one in the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe and the other in the inferior right hilum; patchy parenchymal opacities and mild peribronchial thickening were present, suggestive of recurrent bronchopneumonia.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: The original lesion had resolved, indicating progression to new nodules.
